TORMENT.deftext:
great pain, agony, suffering

TORMENT is great pain and suffering.

“We could tell that our cat was in TORMENT because every few minutes he would give a great cry of pain."

Mental suffering can also be TORMENT.

“The missing boy’s parents were in TORMENT.”

TORMENT is also a verb which means “to cause great pain to,” to torture. As a verb the word is pronounced torment’ or torment.

“He was TORMENTED by a severe headache.”

Sometimes it simply means to annoy.

“He constantly teases and TORMENTS his sister.”

SLACKEN.deftext:
to slow down; to make looser

SLACKEN means to slow down.

“The runner SLACKENED his pace when his leg began to hurt.”

“We enjoyed being on the beach once the wind SLACKENED.” SLACKEN is also used to mean “to make looser.”

“The horse was easier to control after Bill learned to SLACKEN the reins."

The adjective form of SLACKEN is SLACK, which means “not busy, or not tense or taut.”

“It was a SLACK season for his business; few customers came to his shop.”

“The rope was SLACK; it hung loosely from the sail.”

SLACK is also a noun.

“There was some SLACK in the rope.”

Other forms of the word: SLACK, adj., n.

QUALIFIED.deftext:
suited, fit, competent; limited, restricted

To QUALIFY a person is to make him fit for something like a job or an award.

“Your score on the test QUALIFIES you for a prize.”

Someone who is QUALIFIED, therefore, is fit or competent for something.

“Both of them were well QUALIFIED for the job.”

“Only QUALIFIED experts should work with bombs.”

“He wasn’t QUALIFIED to run in the race because he didn’t enter on time.”

Another meaning of QUALIFIED is limited, restricted. To give your “QUALIFIED approval” to something is to approve it with some limitations, not wholeheartedly.

Other forms of the word: QUALIFICATION, n.

QUALIFY, v.

RESTRAIN.deftext:
to hold back, curb, limit, restrict

To RESTRAIN someone is to hold him back from doing something.

“We held on to Bill to RESTRAIN him from hitting the other boy.”

“It was difficult for him to RESTRAIN his temper. He got angry very easily.”

“She could not RESTRAIN a smile at the child’s question.”

RESTRAINT is the noun from RESTRAIN. A RESTRAINT is something that holds you back.

“The prisoner hated the RESTRAINTS that had been placed on his freedom.”

RESTRAINT is also the act of holding back.

“We must exercise RESTRAINT in eating the cookies” -that is, we must hold back our desire to eat too many of them.

Other forms of the word: RESTRAINT, n.

SLUMBER.deftext:
sleep SLUMBER means sleep, usually peaceful sleep.

SLUMBER can be used as either a noun or a verb.

“The baby is quietly SLUMBERING in his crib.”

“As soon as the medicine took effect, he fell into a deep SLUMBER.”

“He lay in peaceful SLUMBER, unaware of the noise.”

CONSUME.deftext:
to use up; to eat; to destroy

CONSUME means to use up, so that there is nothing left.

“By the end of the winter all the firewood we had cut was CONSUMED.”

“Her pay is CONSUMED by the necessary things like food and rent, so there’s nothing left over for fun.”

CONSUME also means to eat or drink; in other words, to use up food.

“We CONSUMED the meal in complete silence.”

“The guests at the party CONSUMED two cases of soft drinks.”

In a slightly different sense, CONSUME can mean to destroy. “Our house and all our belongings were CONSUMED in the fire.”

Other forms of the word: CONSUMER, n.

SUMMON.deftext:
to send for, call together, call forth

To SUMMON someone is to send for him, to ask or require him to come. The word usually suggests that the re- quest is urgent, or that the person doing the SUMMONING is powerful and not to be disobeyed.

“The king SUMMONED all the noblemen to his castle.”

“The ringing of the bell SUMMONED them to their next class.”

To SUMMON up something is to call it forth.

“She tried to SUMMON up a smile, but she was just too unhappy.”

In law, a SUMMONS is a notice ordering a person to appear in court.

“When the witness didn’t appear in court, the judge is- sued a SUMMONS requiring him to come.”

Other forms of the word: SUMMONS, n.

TOLERATE.deftext:
to bear, stand, put up with, endure

TOLERATE means to bea or put up with. The word suggests that you don’t like something, but you endure it because you have to, or because it’s not bad enough to make you resist it.

“Harry doesn’t like children, but he TOLERATES them when he’s visiting friends who have children.”

“She couldn’t TOLERATE having the puppy jump up on her.”

People who TOLERATE things are called TOLERANT.

“He’s very TOLERANT of little mistakes, but she yells about everything.”

Other forms of the word: TOLERANCE, n.

TOLERANT, adj.

UNSETTLE.deftext:
to disturb, make troubled, make uncertain

One meaning of the verb SETTLE is to calm.

“This medicine will SETTLE your stomach if you are not feeling well.”

UNSETTLE is the opposite of SETTLE used in this sense. To UNSETTLE is to make someone or something disturbed or disordered.

“Monica’s attitude of superiority UNSETTLED Julia.”

“The UNSETTLED conditions at the end of the war eventually calmed down during the years of peace that followed.”

“Her final remark was very UNSETTLING. He worried about it all the way home.”

VOW.deftext:
a promise, oath

A VOW is a solemn promise or oath, often taken in some kind of ceremony.

“He made a solemn VOW to find the person who had killed her.”

“She took a VOW of secrecy when she joined the club.” VOW is also a verb meaning to promise or swear. “We VOW to be true to one another forever.”

“Scarlett VOWED that she would never go hungry again.”

CRISIS.deftext:
an emergency, climax, turning point

CRISIS comes from a Greek word meaning decision. A CRISIS is a point at which what happens in the future, good or bad, is decided. In medicine, for example, a CRI- SIS is the turning point in a serious disease, when the patient either starts to get better or dies.

“There was a political CRISIS in that country. No one knew who the next ruler would be."

“She was in the middle of a personal CRISIS then. Her husband was deciding whether he wanted a divorce.”

“That was quite a CRISIS. I’m glad things worked out all right.”

EPISODE.deftext:
an incident, scene, occurrence, one of a series of events

An EPISODE is a scene, incident, or story which is com- plete and interesting in itself, but which is also part of a larger story or series of events.

“The play had some exciting EPISODES, but in general was not very good.”

“It was not a very pleasant EPISODE in his career.”

Single programs in a television series are called EPISODES because they are complete by themselves, but are also part of the entire series.

Other forms of the word: EPISODIC, adj.

WEARY.deftext:
tired, worn out

WEARY means just about the same as tired, although it is a little stronger and suggests someone who has lost most of his energy or his interest.

“After the fifty mile march the soldiers were WEARY and ready for bed.”

“We were all WEARY by the time we had finished cleaning the house.”

WEARY is often followed by of.

“I am getting very WEARY of people always yelling at me.”

WEARY is also a verb, meaning to tire or become tired.

“They began to WEARY of the noise and confusion of city life.”

Unhappy is often chosen as the meaning of WEARY in the Pretest. Someone can be both physically WEARY and happy, though.

“The team was WEARY after the long game, but happy because they had won.”

Other forms of the word: WEARINESS, n.

WOE.deftext:
sorrow, trouble, grief

WOE is deep sorrow or misery.

“The field was a scene of WOE after the battle.”

In a related sense, a WOE is also a cause of sorrow or suffering, a trouble or misfortune.

“His WOES began when he fell and broke his leg.”

“She complained for hours about all the WOES of her life.”

The adjective form of WOE is WOEFUL. WOEFUL can mean unhappy.

“Jane had a WOEFUL look on her face when she heard the bad news.”

WOEFUL can also mean “of very poor quality,” wretched.

“This house is in WOEFUL condition. It needs a lot of work.”

Other forms of the word: WOEFUL, adj.

COMPLIMENT.deftext:
praise

A COMPLIMENT is a polite expression of praise or approval. When you tell people that you admire them or ap- prove of what they’re doing, you are giving them a COMPLIMENT.

“She received several COMPLIMENTS from her friends about her new dress.”

COMPLIMENT is also a verb and means “to express approval of or to give praise to.” As a verb the word is pronounced kom’-pl;)-ment.

“The teacher COMPLIMENTED him for raising his grade in French.”

“She COMPLIMENTED the way we cleaned the house.

Other forms of the word COMPLIMENTARY, adj.

Should someone who wants to commit murder be RESTRAINED?

Pat was TORMENTED by the thought that he would soon have to take the test.
She SLACKENED them for not trying hard enough.
We felt that she was QUALIFIED for the job as an interpreter because she spoke French perfectly.
Gail disliked any RESTRAINTS on her activity. She wanted to do as she pleased.
The car SLUMBERED to a stop by the side of the road.
The climb up the mountain CONSUMED all our energy.
Cindy SUMMONED up all her remaining strength for the last mile of the race.
I simply cannot TOLERATE cigarette smoke.
She was UNSETTLED by the news that she might lose her job.
They received a beautiful blue VOW for a wedding present.
He survived one CRISIS after another during his career.
He called the Civil War one of the saddest EPISODES in American history.
Carla quickly began to WEARY of her dull job at the factory.
Her WOEFUL look told us that she was deeply unhappy.
Dick didn't think she meant it when she COMPLIMENTED him. He felt she was just praising him to make him feel better.
